   Assessment and Plan
   # CORONARIES: Patient presented with STEMI. During cath patient had
   successful thrombectomy of proximal LAD occlusion with 20% residual
   stenosis. However, developed acute occlusion of OM (due to an embolus)
   treated with thrombectomy and PTCA (2.5x12mm balloon) with a 60%
   residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow. Patient was
   unstable during procedure and consequently was intubated and IABP
   placed. No stent was placed during procedure.
   - Continue integrillin 18 hours post cath -> now discontinued
   - Continue heparin while on IABP
   - Patient on Atorvastatin 10 mg outpatient, increase to 80 mg in
   setting of ACS
   - Continue dopamine for goal MAP 60, attempt to wean -> unable to wean
   overnight
   - will attempt to wean IABP today, will reach goal PA diastolic
   pressure of 25 via volume, then attempt to wean to 1:2, obtain SvO2,
   PaO2, and Hb and calculate cardiac index; if data shows stability, will
   continue 1:4, 1:8 as able
   - if pt tolerates 1:8 for 2 hours, will switch off heparin, switch to
   1:1, and remove IABP
   - Hold outpatient Lisinopril 10 mg due to hypotension
   - No B-blocker due to hypotension
   - Start ASA 325 mg
   - Start plavix in am for 12 months (however no stent placed)
   .
   # PUMP: ECHO s/p cath demonstrates EF 45% with mild regional left
   ventricular systolic dysfunction and dilated right ventricle with
   moderate regional systolic dysfunction. New changes secondary to ACS.
   Repeat TTE shows little change while on IABP 1:1
   - Patient will require ACE-I and B-blocker as outpatient, however cont
   to hold due to hypotension
   - Held outpatient Lasix 20 mg qd due to hypotension, no sign of volume
   overload
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus. Patient has history of A Fib, patient presumably on
   Verapamil for rate control. No anti-coagulation due to prior history of
   GI bleed.   Repeat ECG this morning showed left axis deviation and RBB
   block -> pt likely has left anterior fascicular block and RBB block,
   and is at high risk to develop complete heart block
   - will consult EP RE: ? indication for temp pacer wire placement ->
   appreciate recs
   - Hold VERAPAMIL 120 mg in setting of hypotension
   - serial ECGs
   .
   # Upper GI bleed: EGD demonstrates friable esophagus with blood clot at
   GE junction. Patient's HCT and hemodynamics currently stable. Due to
   ballon pump patient must remain on heparin anti-coagulation.
   Integrelin stopped this AM.
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **], carafate slurry 1 g QID, reglan per GI
   - appreciate GI recs -> if UGIB recurs, will contact GI for possible
   repeat endoscopy. Patient may require Sang-[**Doctor Last Name 4220**] tube
   - IR aware of pt, can contact if need for emergent embolization
   - q4hr HCT -> 26 this AM, will transfuse 2 units today
   - cross match 4 units
   - wean ballon pump today in order to stop heparin  .
   .
   # Diabetes: Insulin drip
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold outpatient Lisinopril, Lasix and Verapamil
   .
   # Chronic Renal Failure: Recent creatinine range as outpatient 1.3 -
   1.9.  Pt now has [**Last Name (un) **] this morning.  Possible etiologies include
   pre-renal physiology, cholesterol emboli, contrast-induced nephropathy,
   ATN, and IABP renal artery obstruction (unlikely given current
   position)
   - renal dose all meds
   - will ensure volume repletion with goal PA diastolic pressure of 25
   mmHg
   - monitor crea
   .
   # Asthma: Patient intubated.
   .
   # Gout: Hold Allopurinal in acute setting.
   .
   # GERD: IV PPI fo now, transition to po when stable.
   .
   FEN: NPO
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin drip, pneumo boots when heparin drip
   discontinued
   -Bowel regimen with senna, colace
   .
   CODE: Full Code - confirmed with [**Last Name (un) **]
   .
   COMM: [**Name (NI) 2729**] [**Name2 (NI) 10371**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10372**], [**Name2 (NI) 9565**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10373**]
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and acute occlusion of the obtuse marginal (OM) artery. He underwent a successful thrombectomy and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with a 60% residual thrombotic occlusion. He was intubated and placed on an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) due to instability during the procedure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 79 beats per minute, blood pressure of 92/35 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. His respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.2 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 10.1 g/dL, and creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL. His cardiac enzymes are elevated, with a troponin-T level of 0.72 ng/mL.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is at high risk of developing complete heart block. He is also at risk of developing upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to his recent endoscopy and the presence of a friable esophagus.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Complete heart block due to the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of left anterior fascicular block and right bundle branch block.
	* Cardiac tamponade due to the patient's recent PCI and the presence of a friable esophagus.
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia due to the patient's prolonged intubation and the presence of a foreign body (endotracheal tube).
	* Ventilator-associated lung injury due to the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's recent endoscopy and the presence of a friable esophagus.
	* Gastrointestinal perforation due to the patient's recent endoscopy and the presence of a friable esophagus.
4. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury due to the patient's recent PCI and the presence of a friable esophagus.
	* Chronic kidney disease due to the patient's pre-existing renal disease.
5. Hematological complications:
	* Bleeding due to the patient's recent PCI and the presence of a friable esophagus.
	* Thrombocytopenia due to the patient's recent PCI and the presence of a friable esophagus.
6. Infectious complications:
	* Sepsis due to the patient's recent PCI and the presence of a friable esophagus.
	* Pneumonia due to the patient's prolonged intubation and the presence of a foreign body (endotracheal tube).

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of hematemesis (upper gastrointestinal bleed), cardiogenic shock, and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). 

The patient has undergone various interventions, including invasive ventilation, arterial line insertion, IABP line insertion, sheath insertion, and PA catheter insertion. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6Â°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 92/35 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99%, and their respiratory rate is 13 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated levels of troponin-T, CK, and CKMB, suggesting acute myocardial infarction. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, with increased levels of ALT and AST. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low potassium level.

The patient's ICU care plan includes management of glycemic control, nutrition, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's hematemesis may continue, leading to further bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiogenic shock and AMI may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiogenic arrest.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient's invasive ventilation may lead to respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or respiratory failure.
4. Infection: The patient's invasive lines and catheters may increase the risk of infection, such as sepsis or endocarditis.
5. Organ dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, suggesting potential liver dysfunction, which may lead to further complications.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's slightly low potassium level may lead to electrolyte imbalance, potentially causing cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.

Close monitoring and aggressive management of the patient's condition are necessary to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual who has been admitted to the ICU. The patient has undergone various invasive procedures, including the placement of an arterial line, IABP line, sheath, and PA catheter.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7Â°C (99.9Â°F), a heart rate of 79 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 92/35 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 99%.

The patient's laboratory results indicate that they have a severe infection, with elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with elevated levels of potassium, magnesium, and phosphorus.

The patient's physical examination reveals a warm skin temperature, normal neurologic examination, and a soft abdomen. The patient's cardiovascular examination is notable for a systolic murmur at the base and apex.

Based on the provided information, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and LDH levels suggest that they may be at risk for developing sepsis, a life-threatening condition characterized by an overwhelming systemic inflammatory response.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's systolic murmur at the base and apex may indicate cardiac dysfunction, which can increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient's abnormal lung function, as indicated by their ABG results, may increase the risk of respiratory complications, such as respiratory failure or pneumonia.
4. Neurologic complications: The patient's abnormal electrolyte levels, particularly the elevated levels of potassium, magnesium, and phosphorus, may increase the risk of neurologic complications, such as seizures, coma, or even brain death.
5. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's abnormal coagulation profile, as indicated by their PT and PTT results, may increase the risk of hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding or hematoma formation.

Based on the provided information, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and to initiate appropriate interventions to prevent or manage potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   # CORONARIES: Patient presented with STEMI. During cath patient had
   successful thrombectomy of proximal LAD occlusion with 20% residual
   stenosis. However, developed acute occlusion of OM (due to an embolus)
   treated with thrombectomy and PTCA (2.5x12mm balloon) with a 60%
   residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow. Patient was
   unstable during procedure and consequently was intubated and IABP
   placed. No stent was placed during procedure.
   - Continue integrillin 18 hours post cath -> now discontinued
   - Continue heparin while on IABP
   - Patient on Atorvastatin 10 mg outpatient, increase to 80 mg in
   setting of ACS
   - Continue dopamine for goal MAP 60, attempt to wean -> unable to wean
   overnight
   - will attempt to wean IABP today, will reach goal PA diastolic
   pressure of 25 via volume, then attempt to wean to 1:2, obtain SvO2,
   PaO2, and Hb and calculate cardiac index; if data shows stability, will
   continue 1:4, 1:8 as able
   - if pt tolerates 1:8 for 2 hours, will switch off heparin, switch to
   1:1, and remove IABP
   - Hold outpatient Lisinopril 10 mg due to hypotension
   - No B-blocker due to hypotension
   - Start ASA 325 mg
   - Start plavix in am for 12 months (however no stent placed)
   .
   # PUMP: ECHO s/p cath demonstrates EF 45% with mild regional left
   ventricular systolic dysfunction and dilated right ventricle with
   moderate regional systolic dysfunction. New changes secondary to ACS.
   Repeat TTE shows little change while on IABP 1:1
   - Patient will require ACE-I and B-blocker as outpatient, however cont
   to hold due to hypotension
   - Held outpatient Lasix 20 mg qd due to hypotension, no sign of volume
   overload
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus. Patient has history of A Fib, patient presumably on
   Verapamil for rate control. No anti-coagulation due to prior history of
   GI bleed.   Repeat ECG this morning showed left axis deviation and RBB
   block -> pt likely has left anterior fascicular block and RBB block,
   and is at high risk to develop complete heart block
   - will consult EP RE: ? indication for temp pacer wire placement ->
   appreciate recs
   - Hold VERAPAMIL 120 mg in setting of hypotension
   - serial ECGs
   .
   # Upper GI bleed: EGD demonstrates friable esophagus with blood clot at
   GE junction. Patient's HCT and hemodynamics currently stable. Due to
   ballon pump patient must remain on heparin anti-coagulation.
   Integrelin stopped this AM.
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **], carafate slurry 1 g QID, reglan per GI
   - appreciate GI recs -> if UGIB recurs, will contact GI for possible
   repeat endoscopy. Patient may require Sang-[**Doctor Last Name 4220**] tube
   - IR aware of pt, can contact if need for emergent embolization
   - q4hr HCT -> 26 this AM, will transfuse 2 units today
   - cross match 4 units
   - wean ballon pump today in order to stop heparin  .
   .
   # Diabetes: Insulin drip
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold outpatient Lisinopril, Lasix and Verapamil
   .
   # Chronic Renal Failure: Recent creatinine range as outpatient 1.3 -
   1.9.  Pt now has [**Last Name (un) **] this morning.  Possible etiologies include
   pre-renal physiology, cholesterol emboli, contrast-induced nephropathy,
   ATN, and IABP renal artery obstruction (unlikely given current
   position)
   - renal dose all meds
   - will ensure volume repletion with goal PA diastolic pressure of 25
   mmHg
   - monitor crea
   .
   # Asthma: Patient intubated.
   .
   # Gout: Hold Allopurinal in acute setting.
   .
   # GERD: IV PPI fo now, transition to po when stable.
   .
   FEN: NPO
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin drip, pneumo boots when heparin drip
   discontinued
   -Bowel regimen with senna, colace
   .

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute anterior myocardial infarction (STEMI), acute systolic and diastolic heart failure, and acute respiratory failure. They have undergone thrombectomy and PTCA procedures, but developed acute occlusion of the omohyoid artery due to an embolus. The patient is currently on IABP and dopamine therapy, and is being monitored closely for signs of improvement or deterioration.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Continued heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (EF 45%)
	* Risk of complete heart block due to left anterior fascicular block and RBB block
	* Potential for cardiac tamponade due to IABP placement
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation
	* Respiratory failure with potential for further deterioration
3. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to IABP, contrast-induced nephropathy, or pre-renal physiology
	* Potential for chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease (ESRD)
4. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) due to friable esophagus and blood clot at the GE junction
	* Risk of further bleeding or perforation
5. Infectious complications:
	* Sepsis or septic shock due to bacteremia or pneumonia
	* Risk of further infections due to prolonged hospitalization and immunosuppression
6. Neurological complications:
	* Cerebral edema or stroke due to cardiac arrest or hypoperfusion
	* Risk of further neurological deterioration
7. Hematological complications:
	* Bleeding or hemorrhage due to anticoagulation therapy or gastrointestinal bleeding
	* Risk of anemia or thrombocytopenia due to blood loss or medication side effects

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust therapy accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU patient who experienced a cardiac arrest and was resuscitated. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is labile, with a systolic pressure ranging from 104 to 179 mmHg, and a diastolic pressure ranging from 41 to 68 mmHg.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has experienced rapid atrial fibrillation and unclear ventricular tachycardia with aberrancy.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and a decreased platelet count.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level is 327 mg/dL, and they are receiving insulin therapy.
* Impaired skin integrity: The patient has a history of skin lesions and is at risk for further skin breakdown.
* Hematemesis: The patient has experienced upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB).
* Shock: The patient has experienced cardiogenic shock, which is likely secondary to their cardiac arrhythmias and coagulopathy.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and ongoing cardiac arrhythmias place them at risk for further cardiac arrests.
* Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and UGIB increase their risk of bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial bleeding, and bleeding into the surgical site.
* Sepsis: The patient's hyperglycemia and history of skin lesions increase their risk of developing sepsis.
* Kidney injury: The patient's hypotension and coagulopathy increase their risk of developing acute kidney injury.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support and ongoing hypoxemia increase their risk of developing respiratory failure.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's UGIB and history of skin lesions increase their risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Infection: The patient's history of skin lesions and respiratory support increase their risk of developing infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI).

To mitigate these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of cardiac instability, bleeding, sepsis, kidney injury, respiratory failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and infection. The patient should also receive aggressive management of their hyperglycemia, coagulopathy, and skin integrity.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and underwent a successful thrombectomy of proximal LAD occlusion with 20% residual stenosis. However, during the procedure, the patient developed acute occlusion of OM (due to an embolus) treated with thrombectomy and PTCA (2.5x12mm balloon) with a 60% residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow.

The patient's current condition is unstable, with ongoing hypotension, requiring continuous dopamine infusion. He is also on heparin infusion for IABP and has a high risk of developing complete heart block due to his pre-existing atrial fibrillation and recent history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient has a number of medical conditions, including chronic renal failure, hypertension, diabetes, and asthma, which require ongoing management. He also has a history of gout and GERD.

The patient's lab results show elevated levels of troponin-T, CK, and LDH, indicating ongoing myocardial damage. His coagulation studies show prolonged PT and PTT, and his fibrinogen level is elevated.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Continue dopamine infusion for goal MAP 60
* Attempt to wean IABP today
* Start ASA 325 mg
* Start plavix in the morning for 12 months
* Hold outpatient Lisinopril 10 mg due to hypotension
* Hold outpatient Lasix 20 mg qd due to hypotension
* Hold VERAPAMIL 120 mg in setting of hypotension
* Consult EP regarding temporary pacer wire placement

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Complete heart block due to pre-existing atrial fibrillation and recent history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding
* Ongoing hypotension and cardiac instability
* Renal failure due to pre-renal physiology, cholesterol emboli, contrast-induced nephropathy, ATN, and IABP renal artery obstruction
* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to friable esophagus and blood clot at GE junction
* Respiratory failure due to ongoing respiratory distress and need for mechanical ventilation
* Sepsis due to ongoing infection and need for antibiotics
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to pre-existing atrial fibrillation and recent history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure his optimal care.

   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient presented with STEMI. During cath patient had
   successful thrombectomy of proximal LAD occlusion with 20% residual
   stenosis. However, developed acute occlusion of OM (due to an embolus)
   treated with thrombectomy and PTCA (2.5x12mm balloon) with a 60%
   residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow. Patient was
   unstable during procedure and consequently was intubated and IABP
   placed. No stent was placed during procedure.
   - Continue integrillin 18 hours post cath -> now discontinued
   - Continue heparin while on IABP
   - Patient on Atorvastatin 10 mg outpatient, increase to 80 mg in
   setting of ACS
   - Continue dopamine for goal MAP 60, attempt to wean -> unable to wean
   overnight
   - will attempt to wean IABP today, will reach goal PA diastolic
   pressure of 25 via volume, then attempt to wean to 1:2, obtain SvO2,
   PaO2, and Hb and calculate cardiac index; if data shows stability, will
   continue 1:4, 1:8 as able
   - if pt tolerates 1:8 for 2 hours, will switch off heparin, switch to
   1:1, and remove IABP
   - Hold outpatient Lisinopril 10 mg due to hypotension
   - No B-blocker due to hypotension
   - Start ASA 325 mg
   - Start plavix in am for 12 months (however no stent placed)
   .
   # PUMP: ECHO s/p cath demonstrates EF 45% with mild regional left
   ventricular systolic dysfunction and dilated right ventricle with
   moderate regional systolic dysfunction. New changes secondary to ACS.
   Repeat TTE shows little change while on IABP 1:1
   - Patient will require ACE-I and B-blocker as outpatient, however cont
   to hold due to hypotension
   - Held outpatient Lasix 20 mg qd due to hypotension, no sign of volume
   overload
   .

   Verapamil for rate control. No anti-coagulation due to prior history of
   GI bleed.   Repeat ECG this morning showed left axis deviation and RBB
   block -> pt likely has left anterior fascicular block and RBB block,
   and is at high risk to develop complete heart block
   - will consult EP RE: ? indication for temp pacer wire placement ->
   appreciate recs
   - Hold VERAPAMIL 120 mg in setting of hypotension
   - serial ECGs
   .
   # Upper GI bleed: EGD demonstrates friable esophagus with blood clot at
   GE junction. Patient's HCT and hemodynamics currently stable. Due to
   ballon pump patient must remain on heparin anti-coagulation.
   Integrelin stopped this AM.
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **], carafate slurry 1 g QID, reglan per GI

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and chronic renal failure, who presented with a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was brought emergently to the catheterization laboratory. During the catheterization procedure, the patient had a successful thrombectomy of the proximal left anterior descending (LAD) occlusion with 20% residual stenosis, but developed an acute occlusion of the obtuse marginal (OM) artery due to an embolus, which was treated with thrombectomy and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with a 60% residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow. The patient was unstable during the procedure and was intubated and placed on an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiovascular: The patient has a sinus rhythm with left axis deviation and RBB block, which is a high-risk condition for developing complete heart block.
* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's blood pressure is stabilized, but the patient is still requiring dopamine to achieve a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60 mmHg.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the patient is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) due to pre-renal physiology, contrast-induced nephropathy, or IABP renal artery obstruction.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and is currently on IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and carafate slurry.
* Coagulation: The patient is on heparin for anti-coagulation, but the patient's platelet count is dropping rapidly.
* Infections: The patient has a risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and stress ulcer.
* Laboratory results:
	+ Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
	+ Hematocrit: 26.5%
	+ Platelet count: 64 K/uL
	+ Creatinine: 2.3 mg/dL
	+ Troponin-T: 21.69 ng/mL
	+ Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
	+ LDH: 1314 IU/L

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing integrillin for 18 hours post-catheterization
* Continuing heparin while on IABP
* Attempting to wean the patient off IABP today
* Monitoring the patient's creatinine level and electrolytes
* Providing prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Continuing insulin drip for glycemic control
* Holding outpatient medications such as lisinopril, lasix, and verapamil due to hypotension
* Consulting the emergency physician for possible temporary pacemaker wire placement
* Considering the patient for sang-[**Doctor Last Name 4220**] tube if the patient's upper gastrointestinal bleeding recurs

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Complete heart block
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Stress ulcer
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Pulmonary embolism
* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding
* Sepsis
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Hypotension
* Hypertension
* Hyperglycemia
* Hypoglycemia

   stenosis. However, developed acute occlusion of OM (due to an embolus)

   residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow. Patient was

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who presented with a STEMI and was treated with thrombectomy and PTCA. She developed acute occlusion of the OM and was intubated and placed on IABP. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and is at high risk of developing complete heart block. She has a low-grade disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and is being treated with heparin and antibiotics. She has a history of chronic renal failure and is at risk of developing acute kidney injury. She is also being treated for upper GI bleeding and has a history of asthma and gout.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient is at high risk of developing complete heart block due to her history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of left anterior fascicular block and right bundle branch block. She may require a pacemaker if her condition worsens.
2. **Coagulopathy:** The patient's low-grade DIC may worsen, leading to bleeding complications or thrombotic events.
3. **Renal Complications:** The patient's chronic renal failure may worsen due to her underlying condition, contrast-induced nephropathy, or acute kidney injury.
4. **GI Bleeding:** The patient's upper GI bleeding may recur, requiring further endoscopy and treatment.
5. **Pulmonary Complications:** The patient's asthma may worsen, leading to respiratory complications.
6. **Infection:** The patient's bacteremia may lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
7. **Cardiovascular Complications:** The patient's underlying coronary artery disease may lead to further cardiac events, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
8. **Hematological Complications:** The patient's low platelet count may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.

**Assessment and Plan:**

The patient will be closely monitored for any signs of worsening cardiac, renal, or GI complications. She will continue to receive antibiotic therapy and anticoagulation therapy to prevent further complications. She will also receive supportive care, including insulin therapy and volume repletion, to manage her underlying conditions. The patient's family has been informed of her condition and code status, and they will be involved in any decisions regarding her care.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 88 year old female with DM, HTN who presented with
   STEMI and was brought emergently to cath lab.
   .
   # Shock with mixed cardiogenic and septic physiology -> CO and CI high,
   SVR low.  Pt systemically vasodilated.
   - will attempt to wean IABP: will discuss with family prior to pulling
   pump, as it could precipitation bradycardia, vagal reflex, bleeding,
   etc.
   - will continue dopamine, titrate to MAP in 60s.   IVF as needed.  Per
   discussion with family, will not add another pressor if needed for BP
   support
   - will transfuse PRBCs as needed
   - continue abx with vanc/cefepime for now, plan to pull lines when
   patient more stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus. Patient has history of A Fib, patient presumably on
   Verapamil for rate control. No anti-coagulation due to prior history of
   GI bleed.   ECG now showing left axis deviation and RBB block -> pt
   likely has left anterior fascicular block and RBB block, and is at high
   risk to develop complete heart block.  Overnight, patient
   intermittently in A fib with fast then slow ventricular response.
   Tends to become hypotensive when rapid or brady.
   - EP consulted, recs appreciated.  No indication for pacemaker at
   present.
   - serial ECGs
   - will continue to monitor and hold off on starting antiarrhythmics at
   present
   .
   # Blood Cx positive: As above, will continue abx, IV fluids for now.
   Will pull lines when patient more stable.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: labs reflect low grade DIC with declining plts.
   - will continue to monitor Hct and Plts, replete as needed
   # CORONARIES: Patient presented with STEMI. During cath patient had
   successful thrombectomy of proximal LAD occlusion with 20% residual
   stenosis. However, developed acute occlusion of OM (due to an embolus)
   treated with thrombectomy and PTCA (2.5x12mm balloon) with a 60%
   residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow. Patient was
   unstable during procedure and consequently was intubated and IABP
   placed. No stent was placed during procedure.
   - Continue integrillin 18 hours post cath -> now discontinued
   - Continue heparin while on IABP
   - Patient on Atorvastatin 10 mg outpatient, increase to 80 mg in
   setting of ACS
   - Continue dopamine for goal MAP 60, attempt to wean -> unable to wean
   overnight
   - will attempt to wean IABP today, will reach goal PA diastolic
   pressure of 25 via volume, then attempt to wean to 1:2, obtain SvO2,
   PaO2, and Hb and calculate cardiac index; if data shows stability, will
   continue 1:4, 1:8 as able
   - if pt tolerates 1:8 for 2 hours, will switch off heparin, switch to
   1:1, and remove IABP
   - Hold outpatient Lisinopril 10 mg due to hypotension
   - No B-blocker due to hypotension
   - Start ASA 325 mg
   - Start plavix in am for 12 months (however no stent placed)
   .
   # PUMP: ECHO s/p cath demonstrates EF 45% with mild regional left
   ventricular systolic dysfunction and dilated right ventricle with
   moderate regional systolic dysfunction. New changes secondary to ACS.
   Repeat TTE shows little change while on IABP 1:1
   - Patient will require ACE-I and B-blocker as outpatient, however cont
   to hold due to hypotension
   - Held outpatient Lasix 20 mg qd due to hypotension, no sign of volume
   overload
   .
   # Upper GI bleed: EGD demonstrates friable esophagus with blood clot at
   GE junction. Patient's HCT and hemodynamics currently stable. Due to
   ballon pump patient must remain on heparin anti-coagulation.
   Integrelin stopped this AM.
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **], carafate slurry 1 g QID, reglan per GI
   - appreciate GI recs -> if UGIB recurs, will contact GI for possible
   repeat endoscopy. Patient may require Sang-[**Doctor Last Name 4220**] tube
   - IR aware of pt, can contact if need for emergent embolization
   - q4hr HCT -> 26 this AM, will transfuse 2 units today
   - cross match 4 units
   - wean ballon pump today in order to stop heparin  .
   .
   # Diabetes: Insulin drip
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold outpatient Lisinopril, Lasix and Verapamil
   .
   # Chronic Renal Failure: Recent creatinine range as outpatient 1.3 -
   1.9.  Pt now has [**Last Name (un) **] this morning.  Possible etiologies include
   pre-renal physiology, cholesterol emboli, contrast-induced nephropathy,
   ATN, and IABP renal artery obstruction (unlikely given current
   position)
   - renal dose all meds
   - will ensure volume repletion with goal PA diastolic pressure of 25
   mmHg
   - monitor crea
   .
   # Asthma: Patient intubated.
   .
   # Gout: Hold Allopurinal in acute setting.
   .
   # GERD: IV PPI fo now, transition to po when stable.
   .
   FEN: NPO
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin drip, pneumo boots when heparin drip
   discontinued
   -Bowel regimen with senna, colace
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and a recent STEMI. She was brought to the cath lab emergently and underwent thrombectomy of the proximal LAD occlusion and OM embolus. She was intubated and an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) was placed.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.5Â°C, HR 90 bpm, BP 107/43 mmHg, RR 7 insp/min, SpO2 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CO 7 L/min, CI 3.8 L/min/m2, SVR low, CVP 17 mmHg
* Respiratory support: Endotracheal tube, ventilator mode CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, Vt 550 mL, RR 12, PEEP 5 cmH2O, FiO2 50%
* Laboratory results: WBC 8.5-11.4 K/uL, Hct 22.4-29.6%, Plt 48-66 K/uL, Cr 2.4-2.8 mg/dL, TCO2 14-15 mmol/L, Glucose 138-156 mg/dL
* Coagulopathy: low-grade DIC with declining plts
* Coronaries: successful thrombectomy of proximal LAD occlusion and OM embolus
* Upper GI bleed: EGD demonstrates friable esophagus with blood clot at GE junction
* Diabetes: insulin drip
* Hypertension: hold outpatient Lisinopril, Lasix, and Verapamil
* Chronic Renal Failure: recent creatinine range 1.3-1.9 mg/dL
* Asthma: patient intubated
* Gout: hold Allopurinal in acute setting
* GERD: IV PPI for now, transition to po when stable

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Bleeding complications from the IABP and arterial lines
2. Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
3. Cardiac arrhythmias due to the patient's history of A Fib and left axis deviation
4. Septic shock due to the patient's low-grade DIC and declining platelet count
5. Upper GI bleed complications, such as perforation or re-bleeding
6. Renal failure due to the patient's pre-existing chronic renal failure and potential ATN
7. Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to the insulin drip
8. Hypotension due to the patient's low blood pressure and potential vasodilation
9. Cardiac tamponade due to the patient's recent catheterization and potential bleeding
10. Infection complications, such as sepsis or endocarditis, due to the patient's recent catheterization and potential bacterial seeding.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and chronic renal failure, who presented with a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was treated with thrombectomy and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). She was intubated and placed on a balloon pump due to hemodynamic instability. Her platelet count is low, and she has a coagulopathy with declining platelets. She has a positive blood culture for coag-positive staph bacteremia and is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.5Â°C (99.5Â°F)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 107/43 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 7 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 48 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 138 mg/dL
* Sodium: 133 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.8 mmol/L
* Chloride: 111 mmol/L
* Carbon dioxide: 27.4 mmol/L
* Glucose: 156 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response
* Low blood pressure
* Decreased peripheral pulses
* Abnormal skin turgor
* Decreased jugular venous distension
* Abnormal breath sounds

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Septic shock due to coag-positive staph bacteremia
* Cardiogenic shock due to myocardial infarction
* Renal failure due to hypotension and pre-renal physiology
* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcer or peptic ulcer disease
* Thrombotic complications due to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and her family has been informed of her poor prognosis. The patient's care plan includes weaning off the balloon pump, titrating down dopamine, and continuing antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a chief complaint of shock, cardiac arrest, and other cardiac-related issues. The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.4Â°C (99.3Â°F)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 107/43 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 7 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial Fibrillation (AF)

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and their cardiac function is impaired, as evidenced by the low cardiac output (CO) and cardiac index (CI). The patient's mixed venous oxygen saturation is 69%, indicating inadequate oxygen delivery to the tissues.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 8.5-12.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.5-13.7 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 48-66 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 2.4-2.8 mg/dL
* Glucose: 138-156 mg/dL
* Other lab results indicate coagulopathy, hyperglycemia, impaired skin integrity, hematemesis (upper gastrointestinal bleed), and myocardial infarction (acute).

The patient's medical history includes allergies to Vioxx, Bactrim, Codeine, and Aspirin, as well as unknown allergies.

The patient is receiving various medications, including insulin, midazolam, fentanyl, heparin sodium, dopamine, and other ICU medications.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac function is impaired, which can lead to cardiogenic shock if not managed promptly.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation profile is abnormal, which can increase the risk of bleeding complications.
3. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose levels are elevated, which can lead to complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic coma if not managed properly.
4. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's skin integrity is compromised, which can increase the risk of infection and other complications.
5. Hematemesis: The patient has a history of upper gastrointestinal bleed, which can lead to further bleeding complications if not managed promptly.
6. Myocardial infarction: The patient has a history of acute myocardial infarction, which can increase the risk of cardiac complications if not managed properly.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical complications, including cardiogenic shock, coagulopathy, hyperglycemia, impaired skin integrity, hematemesis, and myocardial infarction. The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve their clinical outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 88 year old female with DM, HTN who presented with
   STEMI and was brought emergently to cath lab.
   .
   # Shock with mixed cardiogenic and septic physiology -> CO and CI high,
   SVR low.  Pt systemically vasodilated.
   - will attempt to wean IABP: will discuss with family prior to pulling
   pump, as it could precipitation bradycardia, vagal reflex, bleeding,
   etc.
   - will continue dopamine, titrate to MAP in 60s.   IVF as needed.  Per
   discussion with family, will not add another pressor if needed for BP
   support
   - will transfuse PRBCs as needed
   - continue abx with vanc/cefepime for now, plan to pull lines when
   patient more stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus. Patient has history of A Fib, patient presumably on
   Verapamil for rate control. No anti-coagulation due to prior history of
   GI bleed.   ECG now showing left axis deviation and RBB block -> pt
   likely has left anterior fascicular block and RBB block, and is at high
   risk to develop complete heart block.  Overnight, patient
   intermittently in A fib with fast then slow ventricular response.
   Tends to become hypotensive when rapid or brady.
   - EP consulted, recs appreciated.  No indication for pacemaker at
   present.
   - serial ECGs
   - will continue to monitor and hold off on starting antiarrhythmics at
   present
   .
   # Blood Cx positive: As above, will continue abx, IV fluids for now.
   Will pull lines when patient more stable.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: labs reflect low grade DIC with declining plts.
   - will continue to monitor Hct and Plts, replete as needed
   # CORONARIES: Patient presented with STEMI. During cath patient had
   successful thrombectomy of proximal LAD occlusion with 20% residual
   stenosis. However, developed acute occlusion of OM (due to an embolus)
   treated with thrombectomy and PTCA (2.5x12mm balloon) with a 60%
   residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow. Patient was
   unstable during procedure and consequently was intubated and IABP
   placed. No stent was placed during procedure.
   - Continue integrillin 18 hours post cath -> now discontinued
   - Continue heparin while on IABP
   - Patient on Atorvastatin 10 mg outpatient, increase to 80 mg in
   setting of ACS
   - Continue dopamine for goal MAP 60, attempt to wean -> unable to wean
   overnight
   - will attempt to wean IABP today, will reach goal PA diastolic
   pressure of 25 via volume, then attempt to wean to 1:2, obtain SvO2,
   PaO2, and Hb and calculate cardiac index; if data shows stability, will
   continue 1:4, 1:8 as able
   - if pt tolerates 1:8 for 2 hours, will switch off heparin, switch to
   1:1, and remove IABP
   - Hold outpatient Lisinopril 10 mg due to hypotension
   - No B-blocker due to hypotension
   - Start ASA 325 mg
   - Start plavix in am for 12 months (however no stent placed)
   .
   # PUMP: ECHO s/p cath demonstrates EF 45% with mild regional left
   ventricular systolic dysfunction and dilated right ventricle with
   moderate regional systolic dysfunction. New changes secondary to ACS.
   Repeat TTE shows little change while on IABP 1:1
   - Patient will require ACE-I and B-blocker as outpatient, however cont
   to hold due to hypotension
   - Held outpatient Lasix 20 mg qd due to hypotension, no sign of volume
   overload
   .
   # Upper GI bleed: EGD demonstrates friable esophagus with blood clot at
   GE junction. Patient's HCT and hemodynamics currently stable. Due to
   ballon pump patient must remain on heparin anti-coagulation.
   Integrelin stopped this AM.
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **], carafate slurry 1 g QID, reglan per GI
   - appreciate GI recs -> if UGIB recurs, will contact GI for possible
   repeat endoscopy. Patient may require Sang-[**Doctor Last Name 4220**] tube
   - IR aware of pt, can contact if need for emergent embolization
   - q4hr HCT -> 26 this AM, will transfuse 2 units today
   - cross match 4 units
   - wean ballon pump today in order to stop heparin  .
   .
   # Diabetes: Insulin drip
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold outpatient Lisinopril, Lasix and Verapamil
   .
   # Chronic Renal Failure: Recent creatinine range as outpatient 1.3 -
   1.9.  Pt now has [**Last Name (un) **] this morning.  Possible etiologies include
   pre-renal physiology, cholesterol emboli, contrast-induced nephropathy,
   ATN, and IABP renal artery obstruction (unlikely given current
   position)
   - renal dose all meds
   - will ensure volume repletion with goal PA diastolic pressure of 25
   mmHg
   - monitor crea
   .
   # Asthma: Patient intubated.
   .
   # Gout: Hold Allopurinal in acute setting.
   .
   # GERD: IV PPI fo now, transition to po when stable.
   .
   FEN: NPO
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin drip, pneumo boots when heparin drip
   discontinued
   -Bowel regimen with senna, colace
   .
   CODE: DNR - confirmed with [**Last Name (un) **].  [**Name (NI) 440**] discussed with family
   escalation of care, but will not withdraw any care at present.  Not
   CMO.  Continue current management.
   .
   COMM: [**Name (NI) 2729**] [**Name2 (NI) 10371**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10372**], [**Name2 (NI) 9565**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10373**]
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease, who presented with a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was taken emergently to the catheterization laboratory. She underwent thrombectomy and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with a successful restoration of flow in the left anterior descending (LAD) and obtuse marginal (OM) arteries. However, she developed acute occlusion of the OM artery due to an embolus, which was treated with thrombectomy and PCI.

The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) and is being treated for cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and coagulopathy. She is receiving dopamine to support her blood pressure, and her cardiac index is high. She is also receiving insulin to control her blood sugar levels.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation (AF) and is taking verapamil for rate control. She is also taking aspirin and clopidogrel for antiplatelet therapy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Complete heart block: Given the patient's history of AF and the presence of left axis deviation and right bundle branch block on her ECG, she is at high risk of developing complete heart block.
	* Ventricular arrhythmias: The patient's recent PCI and the presence of a left anterior fascicular block on her ECG may increase her risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia: The patient's recent intubation and the presence of a tracheostomy tube may increase her risk of developing pneumonia.
	* Respiratory failure: The patient's recent respiratory failure may lead to chronic respiratory failure if not managed properly.
3. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury: The patient's recent PCI and the use of contrast agents may increase her risk of developing acute kidney injury.
	* Chronic kidney disease: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and the presence of diabetes may increase her risk of developing chronic kidney disease.
4. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's recent upper gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to chronic gastrointestinal bleeding if not managed properly.
	* Gastrointestinal obstruction: The patient's recent upper gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to gastrointestinal obstruction if not managed properly.
5. Infection complications:
	* Sepsis: The patient's recent septic shock may lead to chronic sepsis if not managed properly.
	* Infections: The patient's recent intubation and the presence of a tracheostomy tube may increase her risk of developing infections.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor her for potential medical complications and to manage her condition aggressively to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and cardiac disease, who presented with ST elevation MI (STEMI) and was treated with intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP).
* She has coag-positive staph bacteremia and is experiencing septic physiology.
* The patient is intubated and receiving dopamine and heparin infusions.
* Her vital signs are stable, but her laboratory results show evidence of coagulopathy, acidosis, and renal dysfunction.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:**
	* The patient has a high risk of developing complete heart block due to her history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of left anterior fascicular block and right bundle branch block.
	* She may experience hypotension when her ventricular response is rapid or bradycardic.
2. **Coagulopathy:**
	* The patient has a low-grade disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with declining platelet counts, but platelet counts are currently stable in the high 40s.
	* She may require further transfusions or platelet support.
3. **Renal Complications:**
	* The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 2.8 mg/dL.
	* She may require renal dose medications and volume repletion to prevent further kidney damage.
4. **Sepsis:**
	* The patient has septic physiology and bacteremia, which increases her risk of developing sepsis-related complications, such as organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, and death.
5. **Gastrointestinal Complications:**
	* The patient has a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) and is at risk of further bleeding due to her coagulopathy and the presence of friable esophagus.
	* She may require further endoscopy or emergent embolization if bleeding recurs.
6. **Infection:**
	* The patient has coag-positive staph bacteremia, which may require further antibiotic treatment and monitoring for signs of infection.
7. **Pulmonary Complications:**
	* The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, which increases her risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
	* She may require further respiratory support and monitoring for signs of respiratory failure.

**Plan:**

* The patient will continue to receive supportive care, including insulin, dopamine, and heparin infusions.
* Her IABP will be weaned off, and she will be transitioned to oral medications as tolerated.
* Further laboratory tests and imaging studies will be ordered as needed to monitor her condition.
* The patient's family has been informed of her poor prognosis and has agreed to withdraw life-sustaining measures.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 88 year old female with DM, HTN who presented with
   STEMI and was brought emergently to cath lab, currently intubated on
   pressors being weaned off a balloon pump, also with coag positive staph
   bacteremia.
   .
   # Shock with mixed cardiogenic and septic physiology -> CO and CI high,
   SVR low.  Pt systemically vasodilated.
   - Poor prognosis discussed with family, pt made CMO.
   - Will wean IABP.  Will not escalate care after pulling IABP.
   - Will titrate down dopamine.
   - Will not further transfuse PRBCs
   - continue abx with vanc/cefepime for now
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus. Patient has history of A Fib, on Verapamil for rate
   control. No anti-coagulation due to prior history of GI bleed.   ECG
   now showing left axis deviation and RBB block -> pt likely has left
   anterior fascicular block and RBB block, and is at high risk to develop
   complete heart block.  Overnight, patient intermittently in A fib with
   fast then slow ventricular response.  Tends to become hypotensive when
   rapid or brady.
   - EP consulted, recs appreciated.  No indication for pacemaker at
   present.
   - serial ECGs
   - will continue to monitor and hold off on starting antiarrhythmics at
   present
   .
   # Blood Cx positive: As above, will continue abx, IV fluids for now.
   Will pull lines when patient more stable.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: labs reflect low grade DIC with declining plts, however
   now stable in high 40s
   - Will continue to monitor Hct and Plts, expect improvement with d/c of
   IABP
   # CORONARIES: Patient presented with STEMI. During cath patient had
   successful thrombectomy of proximal LAD occlusion with 20% residual
   stenosis. However, developed acute occlusion of OM (due to an embolus)
   treated with thrombectomy and PTCA (2.5x12mm balloon) with a 60%
   residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow. Patient was
   unstable during procedure and consequently was intubated and IABP
   placed. No stent was placed during procedure.
   - Continue heparin while on IABP
   - Patient on Atorvastatin 10 mg outpatient, increase to 80 mg in
   setting of ACS
   - Continue dopamine for goal MAP 60, attempt to wean -> unable to wean
   overnight
   - will attempt to wean IABP today, 1:8 as able
   - if pt tolerates 1:8 for 2 hours, will switch off heparin, switch to
   1:1, and remove IABP
   - Holding outpatient Lisinopril 10 mg due to hypotension
   - No B-blocker due to hypotension
   - Continue ASA 325 mg
   - Continue plavix in am for 12 months (however no stent placed)
   .
   # PUMP: ECHO s/p cath demonstrates EF 45% with mild regional left
   ventricular systolic dysfunction and dilated right ventricle with
   moderate regional systolic dysfunction. New changes secondary to ACS.
   Repeat TTE shows little change while on IABP 1:1.
   - Patient will require ACE-I and B-blocker as outpatient, however cont
   to hold due to hypotension
   - Held outpatient Lasix 20 mg qd due to hypotension, no signs of volume
   overload currently
   .
   # Upper GI bleed: EGD demonstrates friable esophagus with blood clot at
   GE junction. Patient's HCT and hemodynamics currently stable. Due to
   ballon pump patient must remain on heparin anti-coagulation.
   Integrelin stopped this AM.
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **], sucralafate 1 g QID, reglan per GI
   - appreciate GI recs -> if UGIB recurs, will contact GI for possible
   repeat endoscopy. Patient may require Sang-[**Doctor Last Name 4220**] tube
   - IR aware of pt, can contact if need for emergent embolization
   - follow crit, has been stable
   - 4 units cross-matched
   - wean ballon pump today in order to stop heparin  .
   .
   # Diabetes: continue insulin gtt
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold outpatient Lisinopril, Lasix and Verapamil for now
   .
   #Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Recent creatinine range as outpatient
   1.3 - 1.9.  Pt now with creatinine to 2.8.  Possible etiologies include
   pre-renal physiology, cholesterol emboli, contrast-induced nephropathy,
   ATN, and IABP renal artery obstruction (unlikely given current
   position).  Renal failure is likely contributing to acidotic state.
   - renal dose all meds
   - will ensure volume repletion with goal PA diastolic pressure of 25
   mmHg
   - monitor creatinine
   .

   .

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. She presented with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was taken emergently to the catheterization laboratory. During the procedure, she developed a clot in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, which traveled to the left circumflex (LCX) artery, and was treated with thrombectomy and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

Currently, the patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, and is being supported with an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP). She has a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and cardiac arrest during this hospitalization.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.5Â°C (99.5Â°F)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 107/43 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 7 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 17 mmHg
* Pulmonary artery pressure (PAP): 14 mmHg (systolic) and 11 mmHg (diastolic)
* Cardiac output (CO): 7 L/min
* Cardiac index (CI): 3.8 L/min/mÂ²
* Mixed venous oxygen saturation: 69%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.1 K/Î¼L
* Hemoglobin: 27.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 48 K/Î¼L
* Creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 138 mg/dL
* Glucose: 156 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* Troponin-T: 21.69 ng/mL
* CK-MB: 75 ng/mL
* CK: 1872 IU/L
* LDH: 1148 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.1 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General appearance: Well-nourished, overweight/obese, anasarca
* Cardiovascular: Irregular rate, no murmurs
* Respiratory: Intubated, CTA bilaterally anteriorly
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present, obese
* Extremities: 1+ bilateral lower extremity edema
* Skin: Warm
* Neurologic: Opens eyes to voice, cannot follow commands

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Shock with mixed cardiogenic and septic physiology, with a poor prognosis
* Weaning of IABP and dopamine
* Titrating down of dopamine
* No further transfusion of packed red blood cells (PRBCs)
* Continue antibiotics with vancomycin and cefepime
* Serial electrocardiograms (ECGs) to monitor for arrhythmias
* Monitoring of hemodynamic instability and sepsis
* Consideration of pacemaker implantation if complete heart block develops

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac arrest due to complete heart block or ventricular fibrillation
* Sepsis or septic shock due to bacteremia
* Acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease due to pre-renal physiology, contrast-induced nephropathy, or IABP renal artery obstruction
* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to upper gastrointestinal bleeding or ischemia
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility and venous stasis
* Anemia or bleeding due to platelet count decline or coagulopathy

Based on the patient's current condition and laboratory results, it is essential to continue monitoring her hemodynamic stability, cardiac function, and renal function closely, and to adjust her treatment plan accordingly.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 88 year old female with DM, HTN who presented with
   STEMI and was brought emergently to cath lab, currently intubated on
   pressors being weaned off a balloon pump, also with coag positive staph
   bacteremia.
   .
   # Shock with mixed cardiogenic and septic physiology -> CO and CI high,
   SVR low.  Pt systemically vasodilated.
   - Call family as patient not improving, discuss poor prognosis as
   patient not improving.  Discuss withdrawal of care.
   - Will pull IABP, as patient not improving on balloon pump and
   platelets low, possibly [**1-9**] balloon pump, also with possible
   bacteremia.  Will not escalate care after pulling IABP.
   - Will titrate down dopamine.
   - Will not further transfuse PRBCs
   - continue abx with vanc/cefepime for now
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus. Patient has history of A Fib, patient presumably on
   Verapamil for rate control. No anti-coagulation due to prior history of
   GI bleed.   ECG now showing left axis deviation and RBB block -> pt
   likely has left anterior fascicular block and RBB block, and is at high
   risk to develop complete heart block.  Overnight, patient
   intermittently in A fib with fast then slow ventricular response.
   Tends to become hypotensive when rapid or brady.
   - EP consulted, recs appreciated.  No indication for pacemaker at
   present.
   - serial ECGs
   - will continue to monitor and hold off on starting antiarrhythmics at
   present
   .
   # Blood Cx positive: As above, will continue abx, IV fluids for now.
   Will pull lines when patient more stable.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: labs reflect low grade DIC with declining plts.
   - Will continue to monitor Hct and Plts
   # CORONARIES: Patient presented with STEMI. During cath patient had
   successful thrombectomy of proximal LAD occlusion with 20% residual
   stenosis. However, developed acute occlusion of OM (due to an embolus)
   treated with thrombectomy and PTCA (2.5x12mm balloon) with a 60%
   residual thrombotic occlusion but restoration of flow. Patient was
   unstable during procedure and consequently was intubated and IABP
   placed. No stent was placed during procedure.
   - Continue integrillin 18 hours post cath -> now discontinued
   - Continue heparin while on IABP
   - Patient on Atorvastatin 10 mg outpatient, increase to 80 mg in
   setting of ACS
   - Continue dopamine for goal MAP 60, attempt to wean -> unable to wean
   overnight
   - will attempt to wean IABP today, will reach goal PA diastolic
   pressure of 25 via volume, then attempt to wean to 1:2, obtain SvO2,
   PaO2, and Hb and calculate cardiac index; if data shows stability, will
   continue 1:4, 1:8 as able
   - if pt tolerates 1:8 for 2 hours, will switch off heparin, switch to
   1:1, and remove IABP
   - Hold outpatient Lisinopril 10 mg due to hypotension
   - No B-blocker due to hypotension
   - Start ASA 325 mg
   - Start plavix in am for 12 months (however no stent placed)
   .
   # PUMP: ECHO s/p cath demonstrates EF 45% with mild regional left
   ventricular systolic dysfunction and dilated right ventricle with
   moderate regional systolic dysfunction. New changes secondary to ACS.
   Repeat TTE shows little change while on IABP 1:1
   - Patient will require ACE-I and B-blocker as outpatient, however cont
   to hold due to hypotension
   - Held outpatient Lasix 20 mg qd due to hypotension, no sign of volume
   overload
   .
   # Upper GI bleed: EGD demonstrates friable esophagus with blood clot at
   GE junction. Patient's HCT and hemodynamics currently stable. Due to
   ballon pump patient must remain on heparin anti-coagulation.
   Integrelin stopped this AM.
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **], carafate slurry 1 g QID, reglan per GI
   - appreciate GI recs -> if UGIB recurs, will contact GI for possible
   repeat endoscopy. Patient may require Sang-[**Doctor Last Name 4220**] tube
   - IR aware of pt, can contact if need for emergent embolization
   - q4hr HCT -> 26 this AM, will transfuse 2 units today
   - cross match 4 units
   - wean ballon pump today in order to stop heparin  .
   .
   # Diabetes: Insulin drip
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold outpatient Lisinopril, Lasix and Verapamil
   .
   # Chronic Renal Failure: Recent creatinine range as outpatient 1.3 -
   1.9.  Pt now has [**Last Name (un) **] this morning.  Possible etiologies include
   pre-renal physiology, cholesterol emboli, contrast-induced nephropathy,
   ATN, and IABP renal artery obstruction (unlikely given current
   position)
   - renal dose all meds
   - will ensure volume repletion with goal PA diastolic pressure of 25
   mmHg
   - monitor crea
   .
   # Asthma: Patient intubated.
   .
   # Gout: Hold Allopurinal in acute setting.
   .
   # GERD: IV PPI fo now, transition to po when stable.
   .
   FEN: NPO
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin drip, pneumo boots when heparin drip
   discontinued
   -Bowel regimen with senna, colace
   .
   CODE: DNR - confirmed with [**Last Name (un) **].  [**Name (NI) 440**] discussed with family
   escalation of care, but will not withdraw any care at present.  Not
   CMO.  Continue current management.
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and chronic renal failure who presented with ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was treated with intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) and thrombectomy. She has developed septic physiology, mixed cardiogenic and septic shock, and is at high risk of developing complete heart block.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic instability with a cardiac index of 7 L/min and systemic vascular resistance (SVR) of 133 mmHg
* Septic physiology with a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 69%
* Low platelet count (48 K/uL) and evidence of coagulopathy
